message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as fever, neck pain, and an enlarged thyroid gland with decreased uptake on scan are suggestive of subacute thyroiditis. This is further supported by the low TSH and normal T3/T4 levels. The symptoms are not consistent with the other options, such as thyroid lymphoma or struma ovarii. Factitious hyperthyroidism involves intentional ingestion of thyroid hormone, which the patient denied.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory results all point towards subacute thyroiditis. The patient has a tender, firm, and enlarged thyroid gland, along with fever and neck pain radiating to the jaw and ears. The elevated ESR also supports the diagnosis. The 123I scan shows decreased uptake, which is typical in subacute thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma and Struma ovarii are less likely based on the clinical presentation and laboratory results. Factitious hyperthyroidism would require intentional ingestion of thyroid hormone, which is not mentioned in the scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and signs of hyperthyroidism along with an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple areas of decreased uptake. This indicates Subacute thyroiditis, which is a self-limited form of thyroiditis that presents with a painful, tender, and enlarged thyroid gland. Thyroid lymphoma presents with a rapidly enlarging thyroid gland, and Struma ovarii presents as a teratoma composed primarily of thyroid tissue in the ovary. Factitious hyperthyroidism usually has normal thyroid gland size and texture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fever, neck pain that radiates to the jaw and ears, and an enlarged and tender thyroid gland, suggest subacute thyroiditis. The high ESR level is also consistent with this diagnosis, as it indicates an inflammatory process. The 123I scan showing decreased uptake supports this diagnosis, as it is consistent with decreased thyroid function. All the other options are less likely based on the patient’s symptoms and laboratory results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory data suggest subacute thyroiditis. The patient has a tender, firm, and enlarged thyroid gland, as well as elevated ESR levels, all indicative of subacute thyroiditis. The fact that the patient is anxious and sweating excessively also suggests hyperthyroidism, which can occur in subacute thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma usually presents with a rapidly enlarging thyroid gland without pain, while Struma ovarii is a rare ovarian tumor that can produce thyroid hormone. Factitious hyperthyroidism is caused by taking excess thyroid hormones, which does not seem to be the case for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical findings, along with the lab results and scan, suggest a diagnosis of subacute thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma would not have tender swelling, and struma ovarii is a rare condition where thyroid tissue is found in an ovarian tumor. Factitious hyperthyroidism is not a likely diagnosis as the patient has no history of taking any medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fever, neck pain, swelling in the throat, and an enlarged thyroid gland suggest subacute thyroiditis. The elevated T3 and T4 levels but low TSH level also support this diagnosis. The multiple areas of decreased uptake on the 123I scan further support subacute thyroiditis over the other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings suggest subacute thyroiditis, which is an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland. The patient has a tender, firm, and enlarged thyroid gland, as well as a decreased uptake on the 123I scan. The increased level of T3 and decreased level of TSH also support this diagnosis. Thyroid lymphoma and struma ovarii are less likely diagnoses based on the patient's presentation and laboratory findings. Factitious hyperthyroidism, in which the patient intentionally takes excessive amounts of thyroid hormone, is also unlikely given the patient's lack of medication use and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, enlarged thyroid gland, and decreased uptake on the 123I scan suggest the most likely diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma usually has a rapid onset of enlargement and is painless. Struma ovarii is a type of ovarian teratoma that contains thyroid tissue and can cause hyperthyroidism, but the symptoms are usually chronic and not acute. Factitious hyperthyroidism is caused by intentional intake of thyroid hormone and is not likely in this patient with no history of medication use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fever, neck pain, and thyroid gland tenderness suggest the most likely diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis. The additional findings of an enlarged thyroid gland with multiple areas of decreased uptake on the 123I scan also support this diagnosis. Thyroid lymphoma would present differently and show different imaging findings. Struma ovarii and factitious hyperthyroidism are less likely given the patient’s clinical presentation and laboratory results.
